You&#39;ll find a full-sized fridge, a gas oven, a gas range, and plenty of storage.</p><p>The bedroom has a window that opens and hardwood flooring. The bedroom will not fit a king or a queen, but should fit a full bed.</p><p>Inside the recently renovated bathroom there are a medicine cabinet, a standard shower, a standard tub, and good storage. There&#39;s also a window that opens in the bathroom.</p><p>It&#39;s rare in NYC, at this price range, to find a building that&#39;s leasing up fast and loved by tenants. Known for a sleek, modern design that curves around LIC's famous PepsiCo sign, the 26-story building was designed by the international award-winning architecture firm, Arquitectonica.<br />Amenity spaces, including a club room, private garden and landscaped terraces, and the building's lobby and club were designed by internationally renowned design firm, Yabu Pushelberg. On the 7th floor a 50-foot pool is set within a skylit space surrounded by a series of glass doors that retract fully, creating a seamless integration with the building's wraparound sundeck. A 3,300 square foot state-of-the-art fitness center with a view of the Brooklyn Bridge and a spa treatment suite are also located on the 7th floor. The 8th floor offers group fitness, Boxing Studio, and private training studios, a Library with a well-curated selection of books and periodicals, a Tween's Den, a Children's Playroom, and a Screening RentHop_12157293|Exchange Place|20 Exchange place|new york city||Espartaco Albornoz|espartaco.albornoz@elliman.com|917-319-4272|https://www.renthop.com/listings/_/_/12157293|3737|1|1|To schedule an appointment please message me with the best phone number that i can reach you on.   Enjoy complimentary yoga and Pilates classes.  Located in the heart of the iconic Financial District, the residences at this building brings modern vitality to an important piece of New York City history. A monument to the economic engines and people that helped to shape the world's commerce, the building's present-day incarnation retains the rich spirit of the past as it provides renters with a wealth of contemporary amenities - at great value.  Designed by the architectural firm Cross & Cross and completed in 1931, the 57-story, steel-framed, granite and limestone structure was originally the Wall Street area headquarters of City Bank Farmers Trust (now CitiBank). It remains a distinctive and prominent feature in the lower Manhattan skyline. Up close, it's apparent that this buildings magnificent Art Deco and classical elements harken to its "moneyed" beginnings. An imposing entrance arch is carved with 11 international coins (which represented the former bank's global presence) and, from the tops of 14 majestic columns, the captains of finance gaze down on those who enter a lobby that retains its glorious, original bank hall attributes.   Inside the residences, modern style and comfort prevail. The apartments feature gorgeous NYC views, tall ceilings (some 11 feet) and modern kitchens with state-of-the-art stainless steel Liebherr and Fisher & Paykel appliances and custom European cabinets. The baths are elegantly appointed with marble floors, contemporary tiling, and custom sinks and vanities.   A short walk from the caverns of Wall Street, this building offers dividends to provide the perfect respite from hard-charging workdays. Depending on the mood, chose to hit the roof deck for breathtaking sunset views of New York harbor; relax or entertain at the Lounge's wet bar or billiards table; or sweat off stress on the state-of-the-art Techno Gym cardio and weight training equipment. A 24-hour concierge and valet service ensure packages, dry cleaning, and other needs will be well taken care of.   Steps from the busy beer bars of Stone Street and mere blocks from the mixologists of the Dead Rabbit and the historic Fraunces Tavern, the rental prices leave budget enough to thoroughly enjoy the nearby socializing, as well as the shopping, dining, and sightseeing of the Financial District, the South Street Seaport, lower Broadway, Brookfield Place, and Brooklyn, which is just one subway stop away. ABOUT THE NEIGHBORHOOD:  Midwood certainly isn't topping anyone's list of most popular New York City neighborhoods, but perhaps its under-the-radar and somewhat insular vibe is part of the appeal. It is more steeped in tradition and perhaps that's because this south-central Brooklyn neighborhood hasn't given in to the rest of Brooklyn's hip factor. Midwood doesn't have many bars but it's got plenty of hookah lounges. It doesn't have many gyms but the streets are quiet and shaded, perfect for long walks. Its cafes don't boast single-origin beans or co-working spaces so much as a comfortable place to meet friends over pastries. One block of mansions gives way to a set of apartment buildings the same way a small shish-kebab cafe sits beside a seller of mink hats and silk stockings.
